title: Highest and lowest paid jobs in the past year – see if yours is on the list
text:

Average weekly earnings for full-time employees reached £585 in April 2019, an increase of 2.9% in 12 months, figures show.

But which industries took home the highest pay - and the worst?

Company bosses, air traffic controllers and marketing and sales directors were the biggest earners this year, according to new government figures.

The Office for National Statistics (ONS) has released the data as part of its Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings.

It found business bosses typically earn 4.% more than they did last year - with a typical salary of £156,209.

In April 2019, the occupation group with the highest median weekly earnings for full-time employees was managers, directors and senior officials, at £862.

(Image: Getty)

This was £278 higher than the UK as a whole. Caring, leisure and other service occupations was the lowest-paid group, at £392 a week.

Meanwhile, sales and customer service workers and caring, leisure and other services, featured in the three lowest-paying occupation groups.

The highest-earning occupation was chief executives and senior officials (£97,708 median full-time annual gross pay).

The data used pay-as-you-earn (PAYE) tax records on a random sample of 1% of workers to get an idea of how much different groups of employees are earning.

10 top-paying jobs for full-time workers

(Image: Getty)

Chief executives: £156,209 Air traffic controllers: £93,955 Marketing and sales directors: £93,372 Legal professionals: £90,791 Financial planners and directors: £87,855 Aircraft pilots and flight engineers: £86,204 Dentist: £82,839 Doctors: £79,769 IT directors: £79,260 Advertising and PR directors: £79,260

10 lowest-paying jobs for full-time workers

New minimum wage rates from April 2019 *the £3.70 rate apples to apprentices under 19 or in their first year

Bar staff: £16,055 Waiters and waitresses: £16,286 Kitchen and catering assistants: £16,604 Leisure and theme park attendants: £16,766 Launderers, dry cleaners and pressers: £17,090 Educational support assistants: £17,170 Beauticians: £17,179 Nursery nurses and assistants: £17,392 Pharmacy assistants: £17,594 Hairdressers and barbers: £17,609

Chief executives of businesses are still the highest earners in the UK, on £156,209 a year before tax in 2018/19.

Air traffic controllers take the second spot with a £93,955 average salary, a figure that's risen by 1.7%.

Meanwhile, marketing and sales directors take home an average of £93,372 a year.

Waiters earn around £16,286 on average making them them the second lowest earners in the UK last year, despite an 8.8% rise in salaries.

Kitchen staff, theme park attendants, educational support assistants and beauticians also feature in the 20 lowest paid jobs.

Nye Cominetti, economic analyst at think tank the Resolution Foundation, added: "Britain’s lowest earners enjoyed the strongest pay rises last year as a result of another big increase in the National Living Wage.

"As a result, their earnings grew at least four times as fast as for Britain’s top earners.

"The strong pay performance for the lowest earners – on both an hourly and a weekly basis – fully vindicates that ambition of both main parties for a higher minimum wage.
